caption: Figure 1: An illustration of Lemma 4.1. Before Θ(T) rounds, the probability of accessing frequency at any time step is at least Ω(1/log T), and we have an overall Ω(1) frequency with high probability.
description: This figure illustrates Lemma 4.1, which provides a lower bound on the frequency with which Algorithm 1 accesses independent samples of the external factor under partial information feedback.  The shaded region represents an initial period of Θ(log T) rounds where the access frequency is not guaranteed. After this initial period, a constant probability of accessing the external factor is established, leading to an overall Ω(1) frequency of access for the remainder of the time horizon.

caption: Figure 2: Regret of Algorithm 1 under different number of total rounds T = 2000 \cdot 2^k for integer 0 ≤ k ≤ 5.
description: This figure shows the relationship between the regret and the number of total rounds (T) under four different settings: (1) degenerate optimal solution with full information feedback, (2) unique non-degenerate optimal solution with full information feedback, (3) degenerate optimal solution with partial information feedback, and (4) unique non-degenerate optimal solution with partial information feedback.  The x-axis represents the total number of rounds (T), while the y-axis represents the regret. Each line represents the average regret across multiple trials, while the shaded area represents the 99% confidence interval. The figure visually demonstrates how the regret scales differently depending on the degeneracy of the optimal solution and the type of information feedback.
